Rails Development with SSL

Posted on Thursday, July 17, 2008

h2. Big Picture "Nginx":http://nginx.net/ will accept connection on ports 80 (http) and https (443). Under SSL/TLS nginx will negotiate the encryption and proxy any requests that it cannot serve to our trusty "mongrel":http://mongrel.rubyforge.com/ running on port 3000. Mongrel doesn't handle encrypted traffic, instead we pass a flag (X_FORWARDED_PROTO) that indicates the request came over SSL. h2. Prerequisites You will need a functioning "Macports":http://macports.com/ installation and a functioning development environment (i.e. you can browse your project at localhost:3000). h2. Conventions @$@ indicates a standard shell prompt.
@#@ indicates the command needs to be run as the root user by assuming root privileges with @sudo@. h3. Install nginx with SSL Support @# port install nginx +ssl@ h3. Make Your Certs Directory @# mkdir -p /opt/local/etc/nginx/certs@
@$ cd /opt/local/etc/nginx/certs@ h3. Make Your Own Certificate Follow the prompts but **MAKE SURE TO USE *.example.com AS YOUR Common Name!**
"http://pastie.org/234929":http://pastie.org/234929
@# openssl req -new -x509 -nodes -days 365 -out server.crt -keyout server.key@ h3. Create an nginx Configuration File Use "http://pastie.org/234927":http://pastie.org/234927 as an example.
Edit out my locations with yours. (i.e. Replace /Users/Andrew/Projects/macchiato with wherever your code lives.)
@# mate /opt/local/etc/nginx/nginx.conf@ h3. Fire Up nginx and Your Mongrel @# /opt/local/sbin/nginx@
@$ script/server@ h3. Check Your DNS @# mate /etc/hosts to make sure app.example.com points to localhost@ h3. Accept Your New Certificate Open https://app.example.com/ in Safari. Select Show Certificate and accept it permanently.
In Firefox you will have to manually import your certificate.
Firefox => Preferences => Advanced => Encryption => View Certificates => Authorities => Import => /opt/local/etc/nginx/certs/server.crt => Make sure Trust this CA to identify web sites is checked => Ok. h3. "ssl_requirement":http://github.com/rails/ssl_requirement/tree/master "ssl_requirement":http://github.com/rails/ssl_requirement/tree/master is the de-facto standard Rails SSL plugin.
